<span class=\"icon-newtab\">\n            </a></p>\n        </div>\n\n    <!-- End Email Alert -->\n<!-- End Email Alert --><!-- Start Citation Alert Link -->\n                        <p>\n<div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper\">\n    <a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert\" href=\"https://myiopscience.iop.org/signin?origin=a0&return=https%3A%2F%2Fiopscience.iop.org%2Fmyiopscience%2Falerts%2Fsubscribe%3FarticleID%3D0004-637X%2F805%2F2%2F184\"><span\n            class=\"icon-alarm icon-alarm--jhp\"></span>Create citation alert</a>\n</div><!-- End Citation Alert Link -->\n                    </div>\n\t\t</div>\n    </div>\n    <!-- Article information ends -->\n<!-- Start Info top-->\n    <!-- end Info top --><div class=\"article-content\">\n\t<span id=\"articleId\" class=\"hide\">0004-637X/805/2/184</span>\n<!-- Start Abstract -->\n    <h2 id=\"artAbst\" class=\"collapse-blocked\">Abstract</h2>\n        <!-- Start article video abstract -->\n\t<!-- End article video abstract -->\n\t<div class=\"article-text wd-jnl-art-abstract cf\" itemprop=\"description\">\n            <P>GRAMORs are GRAvitationally highly magnified yet MORphologically regular images. An example of this phenomenon was discovered in the cluster MACS J1149.5+2223 in 2009. We investigate the lens statistics of GRAMORs in detail. Assuming a NFW profile for a sample of clusters, we calculate the expected number and redshift distribution of GRAMORs using parameters from COSMOS data for the number density of the background galaxy. A model with a cluster placed at <I>z</I> = 0.544 based on <I>WMAP</I>5 cosmology predicts the redshift of a GRAMOR at <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$z\\simeq 1.49$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/apj512980ieqn1.gif\"></IMG> which is close to the observed <I>z</I> = 1.4906. These results show that the expected number of GRAMORs is about two per cluster in the most likely case, and thus a large number of GRAMORs would be observed in a systematic survey. The probability distribution function of source redshift for GRAMORs depends strongly on dark energy and may be useful for constraining the nature of dark energy.</P></div>\n    <!-- End abstract -->\n<!-- Start Export citation and abstract tools -->\n\t<p>\n\t\t<small>Export citation and abstract</small>\n\t\t<span class=\"btn-multi-block\">\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/805/2/184&doi=10.1088/0004-637X/805/2/184&exportFormat=iopexport_bib&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-bib\" title=\"Export BibTex\">BibTeX</a>\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/805/2/184&doi=10.1088/0004-637X/805/2/184&exportFormat=iopexport_ris&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-ris\" title=\"Export RIS\">RIS</a>\n\t\t</span>\n\t</p>\n<!-- End Export citation and abstract tools -->\n<!-- Start AAS Related Links -->\n<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon bdt-1 mt-2 mb-2 wd-jnl-art-article-aas-related-links\">\n  <div class=\"replica-h3 mt-0\">\n    <a href=\"#\" class=\"reveal-trigger\" data-reveal-label-alt=\"Hide related links\">Related links</a>\n  </div>\n  <div class=\"reveal-content\">\n    <div class=\"article-meta\"> \n      <ul>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2015ApJ...805..184M\" target=\"_blank\">NASA ADS Record <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/cgi-bin/nph-objsearch?refcode=2015ApJ...805..184M&search_type=Search \" target=\"_blank\">NED Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-ref?querymethod=bib&simbo=on&bibcode=2015ApJ...805..184M\" target=\"_blank\">Simbad Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"/journal/0004-637X/page/About%20Related%20Links\" target=\"_blank\">About Related Links</a></li>\n      \t</ul>\n    </div>\n  </div>\n</div>\n<!-- Start info bottom -->\n    <!-- End info bottom -->\n<!-- Start article full text -->\n\t<div xmlns:book=\"http://api.iop.org/Book/1.0/\" itemprop=\"articleBody\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-full-text article-text\">\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj512980s1\" name=\"apj512980s1\">1.\u00a0INTRODUCTION</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Since first being observed (Walsh et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib31\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib31\">1979</a>), strong gravitational lensing has become an important tool for studying various aspects of cosmology (e.g., Gavazzi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib12\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib12\">2007</a>; Coles <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib6\">2008</a>; Barnab\u00e8 et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib2\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib2\">2009</a>). For example, the statistics of strong lensing events are known to have useful information about the evolution of the number density of lensing objects (Mao <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib16\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib16\">1991</a>; Mao &amp; Kochanek <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib17\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib17\">1994</a>; Capelo &amp; Natarajan <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib5\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib5\">2007</a>; Matsumoto &amp; Futamase <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib18\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib18\">2008</a>) as well as cosmological parameters (Turner et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib30\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib30\">1984</a>; Fukugita et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib10\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib10\">1992</a>). In the past, poor and inhomogeneous sampling of images and uncertainty regarding the distribution of the background galaxies prevented the useful application of lens statistics to cosmology. However, recent developments in observational astronomy such as the SDSS (York et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib33\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib33\">2000</a>) and COSMOS projects (Scoville et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib28\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib28\">2007</a>) make the accurate prediction of lens statistics and a detailed comparison with observational data possible (Mitchell et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib20\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib20\">2005</a>; Faure et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib7\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib7\">2008</a>; Oguri et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib23\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib23\">2008</a>) and is expected to continue in the future.</p><p>Given this situation, it is worthwhile to study lens statistics from a new point of view. Lens statistics have been studied for quasars (Lopes &amp; Miller <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib15\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib15\">2004</a>; Mitchell et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib20\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib20\">2005</a>; Allen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib1\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib1\">2008</a>; Oguri et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib23\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib23\">2008</a>) and giant luminous arcs (Turner et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib30\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib30\">1984</a>; Bartelmann <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib3\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib3\">1996</a>; Bartelmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib4\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib4\">1998</a>; Oguri et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib22\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib22\">2001</a>; Meneghetti et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib19\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib19\">2013</a>). Here we consider the statistics for GRavitationally highly magnified yet MORphologically regular images (GRAMORs) as predicted by Williams &amp; Lewis (Williams &amp; Lewis <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib32\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib32\">1998</a>) and Futamase, Hattori &amp; Hamana (Futamase et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib11\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib11\">1998</a>). One of the reasons we study GRAMORs is their discovery in the cluster MACS J1149.5+2223 at redshift 0.544 (Zitrin &amp; Broadhurst <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib34\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib34\">2009</a>). The image is a spiral galaxy at redshift 1.4906 with area 55<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/squ.gif\" alt=\"squ\" align=\"baseline\" />'' and is observed near the center of the cluster as one of multiple images. The area of all lensed images covers 150<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/squ.gif\" alt=\"squ\" align=\"baseline\" />'' with a magnification estimated to be ~200 in total. Mass reconstruction using multiple images showed a very flat mass profile (Smith et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib27\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib27\">2009</a>; Zitrin &amp; Broadhurst <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib34\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib34\">2009</a>). This fact is consistent with the theoretical prediction that a mass distribution with a flat central core can easily produce undistorted images (Futamase et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib11\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib11\">1998</a>; Williams &amp; Lewis <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib32\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib32\">1998</a>). The other reason is the expectation that the statistics of GRAMORs will depend strongly on cosmological parameters. Lens statistics depends in general on the cosmological parameters, in particular the existence of dark energy (Fukugita et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib9\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib9\">1990</a>; Hamana et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib13\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib13\">1997</a>; Futamase et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib11\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib11\">1998</a>). In the case of GRAMORs, the conditions needed for their formation is more strict compared with giant luminous arcs, and thus the appropriate combination of cosmological parameters will be more restricted. Since the statistics depend not only on the cosmological parameters but also on the lensing object and background source, it is crucial to use realistic models for the lensing object and sources to make a realistic prediction. We shall make use of the observed sample of clusters (LoCuSS sample) as our model of lensing clusters (Okabe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib24\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib24\">2010</a>) and COSMOS data for the number density of the background galaxies (Fu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib8\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib8\">2008</a>; Ilbert et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib14\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib14\">2009</a>). We find that this expectation is, in fact, the case.</p><p>This paper is organized as follows. In Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj512980s2\">2</a>, we describe the basic properties of the NFW lens model and give the definition of GRAMORs. In Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj512980s3\">3</a> we summarize the observed GRAMOR based on previous work. In Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj512980s4\">4</a> we describe our calculation of the lens statistics and the assumptions in detail. The results of the calculation are given in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj512980s5\">5</a> where we will show the dependence of the results on the lens model and redshift. In particular we will find a strong dependence on dark energy. Finally, the conclusions and discussion are presented in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj512980s6\">6</a>.</p><p>Throughout this paper we use the cosmological parameters taken from <em>WMAP</em>5 data, (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn2.gif\" alt=\"${{{\\Omega }}_{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{{\\Omega }}_{m}}</script></span></span>,<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn3.gif\" alt=\"${{{\\Omega }}_{{\\Lambda }}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{{\\Omega }}_{{\\Lambda }}}</script></span></span>) = (0.27, 0.73), <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 100<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn4.gif\" alt=\"${{h}^{-1}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{h}^{-1}}</script></span></span> km <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn5.gif\" alt=\"${{{\\rm s}}^{-1}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{{\\rm s}}^{-1}}</script></span></span> Mp<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn6.gif\" alt=\"${{{\\rm c}}^{-1}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{{\\rm c}}^{-1}}</script></span></span>, and <em>h</em> = 0.73 unless otherwise noted.</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj512980s2\" name=\"apj512980s2\">2.\u00a0BASIC KNOWLEDGE OF THE GRAVITATIONAL LENSING</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><h3 id=\"apj512980s2-1\" name=\"apj512980s2-1\">2.1.\u00a0Basic Equations</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The basic equation of gravitational lensing is the lensing equation,</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn1\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn1.gif\" alt=\"Equation (1)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\boldsymbol{ \\beta }} ={\\boldsymbol{ \\theta }} -{\\boldsymbol{ \\alpha }} ({\\boldsymbol{ \\theta }} ),\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t1\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn7.gif\" alt=\"${\\boldsymbol{ \\beta }} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\boldsymbol{ \\beta }}</script></span></span> is the 2D angular position vector in the source plane, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn8.gif\" alt=\"${\\boldsymbol{ \\theta }} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\boldsymbol{ \\theta }}</script></span></span> is the 2D angular position vector in the image plane and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn9.gif\" alt=\"${\\boldsymbol{ \\alpha }} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\boldsymbol{ \\alpha }}</script></span></span> is the deflection angle projected onto the sky. For the spherical lens model, we can write the deflection angle simply using the mass <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn10.gif\" alt=\"$M(\\lt \\theta )$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">M(\\lt \\theta )</script></span></span> enclosed within the radius <em>\u03b8</em> as follows.</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn2\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn2.gif\" alt=\"Equation (2)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\boldsymbol{ \\alpha }} =\\frac{4G}{{{c}^{2}}}\\frac{{{D}_{d}}{{D}_{ds}}}{{{D}_{s}}}M(\\lt \\theta )\\frac{{\\boldsymbol{ \\theta }} }{{{\\theta }^{2}}}\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t2\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn11.gif\" alt=\"$M(\\lt \\theta )$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">M(\\lt \\theta )</script></span></span> is the integrated surface mass density <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn12.gif\" alt=\"${\\Sigma }(\\theta )$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\Sigma }(\\theta )</script></span></span>, </p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn3\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn3.gif\" alt=\"Equation (3)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&M(\\lt \\theta )=\\int _{0}^{\\theta }2\\pi {{\\theta }^{\\prime }}{\\Sigma }({{\\theta }^{\\prime }})d{{\\theta }^{\\prime }}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t3\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>Here, we introduce the convergence <em>\u03ba</em>, the dimensionless surface mass density,</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn4\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn4.gif\" alt=\"Equation (4)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\kappa (\\theta )=\\frac{{\\Sigma }(\\theta )}{{{{\\Sigma }}_{{\\rm cr}}}},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t4\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn13.gif\" alt=\"${{{\\Sigma }}_{{\\rm cr}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{{\\Sigma }}_{{\\rm cr}}}</script></span></span> the critical surface mass density defined by</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn5\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn5.gif\" alt=\"Equation (5)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{{{\\Sigma }}_{{\\rm cr}}}=\\frac{{{c}^{2}}}{4\\pi G}\\frac{{{D}_{s}}}{{{D}_{d}}{{D}_{ds}}},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t5\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn14.gif\" alt=\"${{D}_{d}},{{D}_{s}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{D}_{d}},{{D}_{s}}</script></span></span> and <em>D</em><sub><em>ds</em></sub> are the angular diameter distances from the observer to the lens, from the observer to the source and from the lens to the source, respectively.</p><p>Using these parameters, we can write the enclosed mass and the lens equation for a spherical lens model with <em>\u03ba</em>. Next, we consider the eigenvalues of the Jacobian matrix <em>A</em>. For the circular lens model, the eigenvalues are expressed</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn6\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn6.gif\" alt=\"Equation (6)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{{\\lambda }_{-}}=1-\\kappa -\\gamma \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t6\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn7\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn7.gif\" alt=\"Equation (7)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&=\\;1+\\frac{1}{\\pi {{{\\Sigma }}_{{\\rm cr}}}}\\left( \\frac{M(\\lt \\theta )}{{{\\theta }^{2}}}-\\frac{1}{\\theta }\\frac{dM(\\lt \\theta )}{d\\theta } \\right)\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t7\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn8\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn8.gif\" alt=\"Equation (8)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{{\\lambda }_{+}}=1-\\kappa +\\gamma =1-\\frac{1}{\\pi {{{\\Sigma }}_{{\\rm cr}}}}\\frac{M(\\lt \\theta )}{{{\\theta }^{2}}}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t8\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p></div><h3 id=\"apj512980s2-2\" name=\"apj512980s2-2\">2.2.\u00a0NFW Lens Model</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>We use the NFW profile (Navarro et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib21\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib21\">1997</a>) as the lens model. The density profile is given by the following formula,</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn9\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn9.gif\" alt=\"Equation (9)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\rho =\\frac{{{\\rho }_{{\\rm crit}}}{{\\delta }_{c}}}{x{{(1+x)}^{2}}},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t9\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn15.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rho }_{{\\rm crit}}}=3\\;{{H}^{2}}/8\\pi G$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rho }_{{\\rm crit}}}=3\\;{{H}^{2}}/8\\pi G</script></span></span> is the critical density, <em>x</em> is the radius in units of a scale radius <em>r</em><sub><em>s</em></sub>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn16.gif\" alt=\"$x\\equiv r/{{r}_{s}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">x\\equiv r/{{r}_{s}}</script></span></span>, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn17.gif\" alt=\"${{\\delta }_{c}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\delta }_{c}}</script></span></span> is a characteristic overdensity and defined as</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn10\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn10.gif\" alt=\"Equation (10)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{{\\delta }_{c}}=\\frac{200}{3}\\frac{{{c}^{3}}}{{\\rm ln} (1+c)-c/(1+c)},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t10\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn18.gif\" alt=\"$c={{r}_{200}}/{{r}_{s}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">c={{r}_{200}}/{{r}_{s}}</script></span></span> is called the concentration parameter and <em>r</em><sub>200</sub> is the radius within which the density is higher than 200 times the averaged density. The lens equation of the NFW profile becomes</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn11\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn11.gif\" alt=\"Equation (11)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&y=x-\\frac{m(x)}{x},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t11\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn19.gif\" alt=\"$y=(\\eta /{{r}_{s}})({{D}_{d}}/{{D}_{s}})$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">y=(\\eta /{{r}_{s}})({{D}_{d}}/{{D}_{s}})</script></span></span>, <em>\u03b7</em> is the position vector in the source plane, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn20.gif\" alt=\"$m(x)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">m(x)</script></span></span> is the projected dimensionless mass profile</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn12\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn12.gif\" alt=\"Equation (12)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&m(x)\\equiv 2\\int _{0}^{x}y\\kappa (y)dy.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t12\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>From Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj512980eqn9\">9</a>), the surface mass density is expressed</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn13\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn13.gif\" alt=\"Equation (13)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\Sigma }(x)=\\frac{2{{\\rho }_{s}}{{r}_{s}}}{{{x}^{2}}-1}f(x),\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t13\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>with</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn14\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn14.gif\" alt=\"Equation (14)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}f(x)=\\left\\{ \\begin{array}{ccccccccccccccc} 1-\\frac{2}{\\sqrt{{{x}^{2}}-1}}{\\rm arctan} \\sqrt{\\frac{x-1}{x+1}} & (x\\gt 1) \\\\ 0 & (x=1) \\\\ 1-\\frac{2}{\\sqrt{1-{{x}^{2}}}}{\\rm arctanh}\\sqrt{\\frac{1-x}{1+x}} & (x\\lt 1). \\\\ \\end{array} \\right.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t14\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>Therefore, the convergence can be written</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn15\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn15.gif\" alt=\"Equation (15)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\kappa (x)=2{{\\kappa }_{s}}\\frac{f(x)}{{{x}^{2}}-1}\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t15\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn21.gif\" alt=\"${{\\kappa }_{s}}\\equiv {{\\rho }_{s}}{{r}_{s}}/{{{\\Sigma }}_{{\\rm crit}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\kappa }_{s}}\\equiv {{\\rho }_{s}}{{r}_{s}}/{{{\\Sigma }}_{{\\rm crit}}}</script></span></span>. Inserting Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj512980eqn20\">20</a>) into (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj512980eqn12\">12</a>), the dimensionless mass <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn22.gif\" alt=\"$m(x)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">m(x)</script></span></span> becomes</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn16\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn16.gif\" alt=\"Equation (16)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&m(x)=4{{\\kappa }_{s}}g(x),\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t16\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn17\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn17.gif\" alt=\"Equation (17)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}g(x)={\\rm ln} \\frac{x}{2}+\\left\\{ \\begin{array}{ccccccccccccccc} \\frac{2}{\\sqrt{{{x}^{2}}-1}}{\\rm arctan} \\sqrt{\\frac{x-1}{x+1}} & (x\\gt 1) \\\\ 1 & (x=1) \\\\ \\frac{2}{\\sqrt{1-{{x}^{2}}}}{\\rm arctanh}\\sqrt{\\frac{1-x}{1+x}} & (x\\lt 1). \\\\ \\end{array} \\right.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t17\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj512980s3\" name=\"apj512980s3\">3.\u00a0GRAMORS</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><h3 id=\"apj512980s3-1\" name=\"apj512980s3-1\">3.1.\u00a0The Definition of GRAMORs</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>GRAMORs means GRAvitationally highly magnified yet MORphologically regular images. We define a GRAMOR using the distortion parameter <em>R</em> and the magnification parameter <em>A</em>. These are defined by the eigenvalues of the Jacobian, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn23.gif\" alt=\"${{\\lambda }_{-}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\lambda }_{-}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn24.gif\" alt=\"${{\\lambda }_{+}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\lambda }_{+}}</script></span></span> as follows.</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn18\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn18.gif\" alt=\"Equation (18)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&R=\\frac{{{\\lambda }_{-}}}{{{\\lambda }_{+}}}\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t18\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>and</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn19\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn19.gif\" alt=\"Equation (19)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&A=\\frac{1}{{{\\lambda }_{-}}{{\\lambda }_{+}}}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t19\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>A GRAMOR is then defined as images which satisfy the condition 1/3 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn25.gif\" alt=\"$\\leqslant $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\leqslant</script></span></span> <em>R</em> <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn26.gif\" alt=\"$\\leqslant $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\leqslant</script></span></span> 3 and 10 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn27.gif\" alt=\"$\\leqslant \\;A$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\leqslant \\;A</script></span></span>. We adopt the above definition based on previous reports (Futamase et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib11\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib11\">1998</a>; Williams &amp; Lewis <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib32\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib32\">1998</a>).</p></div><h3 id=\"apj512980s3-2\" name=\"apj512980s3-2\">3.2.\u00a0The Observed GRAMOR</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The first GRAMOR was discovered by Zitrin and Broadhurst in 2009 in the center of MACS J1149.5+2223. Here we summarize the properties of the observed GRAMOR. It is observed in the center of MACS J1149.5+2223, an X-ray luminous cluster at <em>z</em> = 0.544. The image is one of multiple images of a blue spiral galaxy at <em>z</em> = 1.4906. It covers an area of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn28.gif\" alt=\"$\\simeq 55\\square ^{\\prime\\prime} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\simeq 55\\square ^{\\prime\\prime}</script></span></span> and magnification is estimated to be <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn29.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu =23$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu =23</script></span></span>. An image of the observed GRAMOR is shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj512980f1\">1</a>, cited from Smith et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib27\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib27\">2009</a>).</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj512980f1\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj512980f1\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f1_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 1.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 1.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f1_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 1.</strong>\u00a0Image of the observed GRAMOR. This figure is excerpted from Smith et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib27\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib27\">2009</a>).</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj512980f1\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadFigure/figure/apj512980f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj512980f1\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj512980f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>According to the lens model of Zitrin and Broadhurst, the diameter of the source for the GRAMOR is about 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5. However, the size of the massive galaxies at <em>z</em> ~ 1.5 is about 1'' (Trujillo et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib29\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib29\">2007</a>). Thus the source of the observed GRAMOR is not a special galaxy. The reconstructed mass distribution by Smith et al, MACS J1149.5+2223, shows a very flat core with a profile expressed by <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn30.gif\" alt=\"$\\kappa \\sim {{\\theta }^{\\gamma }}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\kappa \\sim {{\\theta }^{\\gamma }}</script></span></span>, where <em>\u03b8</em> is the position angle in the lens plane and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn31.gif\" alt=\"$\\gamma \\sim -0.3\\pm 0.05$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\gamma \\sim -0.3\\pm 0.05</script></span></span> in the range 3'' <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn32.gif\" alt=\"$\\leqslant \\;\\theta \\;\\leqslant \\;30^{\\prime\\prime} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\leqslant \\;\\theta \\;\\leqslant \\;30^{\\prime\\prime}</script></span></span>. This range corresponds to 19 kpc <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn33.gif\" alt=\"$\\leqslant \\;r\\;\\leqslant $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\leqslant \\;r\\;\\leqslant</script></span></span> 190 kpc, where <em>r</em> is the distance from the cluster center in the lens plane.</p><p>In order to use this profile as a lens model in later calculations, we determine the proportional coefficient of the power law <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn34.gif\" alt=\"${{\\theta }^{\\gamma }}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\theta }^{\\gamma }}</script></span></span>. </p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn20\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn20.gif\" alt=\"Equation (20)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\kappa =K({{z}_{s}}){{\\theta }^{-0.3}}\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t20\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where the proportional constant <em>K</em> has a source redshift dependence. By comparing Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj512980eqn20\">20</a>) with Figure 4 in Smith et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib27\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib27\">2009</a>), we obtain <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn35.gif\" alt=\"${{K}_{1.5}}\\equiv K({{z}_{s}}=1.5)=1.905$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{K}_{1.5}}\\equiv K({{z}_{s}}=1.5)=1.905</script></span></span>. Since the convergence has a redshift dependence <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn36.gif\" alt=\"${{D}_{ds}}/{{D}_{s}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{D}_{ds}}/{{D}_{s}}</script></span></span>, we have</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn21\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn21.gif\" alt=\"Equation (21)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&K(z)={{K}_{1.5}}\\frac{{{D}_{ds}}(z)/{{D}_{s}}(z)}{{{D}_{ds}}({{z}_{s}}=1.5)/{{D}_{s}}({{z}_{s}}=1.5)}=3.5\\frac{{{D}_{ds}}}{{{D}_{s}}}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t21\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>This is expressed in arcseconds. By transforming into radians, we use the following form for the lens profile of MACSJ1149.5+2223 in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj512980s5\">5</a>.</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn22\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn22.gif\" alt=\"Equation (22)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\kappa =0.089\\frac{{{D}_{ds}}}{{{D}_{s}}}\\theta _{{\\rm rad}}^{-0.3}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t22\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj512980s4\" name=\"apj512980s4\">4.\u00a0ANALYSIS</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><h3 id=\"apj512980s4-1\" name=\"apj512980s4-1\">4.1.\u00a0Lens Statistics</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>In order to determine the expected number of GRAMORs, we introduce the cross section <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn37.gif\" alt=\"${{\\sigma }_{s}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\sigma }_{s}}</script></span></span> in the source plane in such a way that the source within the cross section makes a GRAMOR. The cross section <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn38.gif\" alt=\"${{\\sigma }_{s}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\sigma }_{s}}</script></span></span> depends on the properties of lens and sources. Then the number of GRAMORs produced by the sources between redshift <em>z</em> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn39.gif\" alt=\"$z+dz$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z+dz</script></span></span> is given by</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn23\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn23.gif\" alt=\"Equation (23)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}\\begin{array}{ccccccccccccccc} dN({{z}_{s}}) & = & n({{z}_{s}}){{\\sigma }_{s}}\\frac{cdt}{d{{z}_{s}}}d{{z}_{s}} \\\\ {} & = & n({{z}_{s}}){{\\sigma }_{s}}\\frac{c}{{{H}_{0}}}\\frac{d{{z}_{s}}}{(1+{{z}_{s}})\\sqrt{{{{\\Omega }}_{0}}{{(1+{{z}_{s}})}^{3}}+{{{\\Omega }}_{{\\Lambda }}}}}, \\\\ \\end{array}\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t23\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn40.gif\" alt=\"$n({{z}_{s}})$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">n({{z}_{s}})</script></span></span> is the number density of the sources as a function of redshift. <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn41.gif\" alt=\"${{{\\Omega }}_{0}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{{\\Omega }}_{0}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn42.gif\" alt=\"${{{\\Omega }}_{{\\Lambda }}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{{\\Omega }}_{{\\Lambda }}}</script></span></span> are the matter density parameter and the dark energy density parameter respectively. The total number of images is obtained by integrating <em>dN</em> from <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn43.gif\" alt=\"$z=\\infty $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z=\\infty</script></span></span>.</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn24\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn24.gif\" alt=\"Equation (24)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}\\begin{array}{ccccccccccccccc} N & = & \\int dN \\\\ {} & = & \\int _{{{z}_{l}}}^{\\infty }n({{z}_{s}}){{\\sigma }_{s}}\\frac{c}{{{H}_{0}}}\\frac{d{{z}_{s}}}{(1+{{z}_{s}})\\sqrt{{{{\\Omega }}_{0}}{{(1+{{z}_{s}})}^{3}}+{{{\\Omega }}_{{\\Lambda }}}}}. \\\\ \\end{array}\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t24\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>We define the probability distribution function (PDF) <em>P</em>(<em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub>) of the source redshift as normalized by the total number of the expected number of GRAMORs.</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn25\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn25.gif\" alt=\"Equation (25)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&P({{z}_{s}})=\\frac{N({{z}_{s}})}{N}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t25\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>This PDF will be used for comparing the results using various sets of cosmological parameters.</p></div><h3 id=\"apj512980s4-2\" name=\"apj512980s4-2\">4.2.\u00a0Sample of Clusters</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>As our lens model, we choose four cluster models suggested by weak lensing observations of 52 LoCuSS clusters (Okabe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib24\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib24\">2010</a>) which is a sample of X-ray clusters with redshifts from 0.15 to 0.3. Based on the results of Okabe et al., we selected 48 out of 52 clusters which are well described by an NFW profile, and are then classified into four types, A to D, based on mass as shown in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj512980t1\">1</a>. In the table, each type of model cluster is obtained by stacking 12 clusters to get the average density profile with the average mass and concentration parameter. Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj512980f2\">2</a> shows the density profiles for these four types of clusters. We set the lens redshift <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub> = 0.2 for all clusters. The smaller the concentration parameter the clusters have, the more flat mass distribution they have, as expected from the definition of the concentration parameter.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj512980f2\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj512980f2\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f2_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 2.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 2.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f2_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 2.</strong>\u00a0Convergence profiles of the four types of clusters evaluated. The solid, dashed, dotted and dotted\u2013dashed lines show results with lens models A, B, C and D, respectively. Lens models with smaller concentration parameters have flatter profiles.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj512980f2\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadFigure/figure/apj512980f2\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj512980f2\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj512980f2\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apj512980t1\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 1.</b>\u00a0\nParameters of the Four Lens Models Used\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj512980t1\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">217.41</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">5.762</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"
