colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">12.678</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">537.83</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">3.663</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Note.</strong>  <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub> is the virial mass, <em>r</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> is the scale radius and <em>c</em> is the concentration parameter.</p>\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/suppdata/apj512980t1_ascii.txt?doi=10.1088/0004-637X/805/2/184\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/suppdata/apj512980t1_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div></div><h3 id=\"apj512980s4-3\" name=\"apj512980s4-3\">4.3.\u00a0The Source Distribution</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The source redshift distribution is needed for calculation of the expected number of images. We use the best-fit function from the COSMOS survey proposed by Ilbert et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib14\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib14\">2009</a>).</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn26\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn26.gif\" alt=\"Equation (26)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&n(z)=A\\frac{{{z}^{a}}+{{z}^{ab}}}{{{z}^{b}}+c}\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t26\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>with</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj512980eqn27\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980eqn27.gif\" alt=\"Equation (27)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&A={{\\left( \\int _{0}^{\\infty }\\frac{{{z}^{a}}+{{z}^{ab}}}{{{z}^{b}}+c}dz \\right)}^{-1}}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t27\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><p><em>A</em> is the normalization factor and <em>a</em>, <em>b</em>, <em>c</em> are free parameters. The best-fit parameters are obtained for each bin from <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn46.gif\" alt=\"$22\\lt {{i}^{+}}\\lt 22.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">22\\lt {{i}^{+}}\\lt 22.5</script></span></span> to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn47.gif\" alt=\"$24.5\\lt {{i}^{+}}\\lt 25$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">24.5\\lt {{i}^{+}}\\lt 25</script></span></span> and these parameters are shown in Table 2 of Ilbert et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib14\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib14\">2009</a>). By adding all distributions, we get the galaxy redshift distribution for <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn48.gif\" alt=\"$22\\lt {{i}^{+}}\\lt 25$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">22\\lt {{i}^{+}}\\lt 25</script></span></span>. This is shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj512980f3\">3</a>. We use this distribution as the number density of the source, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn49.gif\" alt=\"$n({{z}_{s}})$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">n({{z}_{s}})</script></span></span>, when we calculate the expected number of GRAMORs.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj512980f3\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj512980f3\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f3_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 3.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 3.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f3_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 3.</strong>\u00a0Distribution of the background galaxies derived from COSMOS data.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj512980f3\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadFigure/figure/apj512980f3\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj512980f3\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj512980f3\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj512980s5\" name=\"apj512980s5\">5.\u00a0RESULTS</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>In this section we present the results of the calculations. The results depend on the lens model used, the definition of GRAMORs, the lens redshift and the cosmological parameters. We will explain each of these dependencies.</p><p>Here, we consider the detectability in terms of the source size. As mentioned in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj512980s2\">2</a>, the source size of the observed GRAMOR is about 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5. However, the size of the massive galaxies at <em>z</em> ~ 1.5 is about 1'' (Trujillo et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib29\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib29\">2007</a>). This means that the source of the observed GRAMOR is not special compared with that of other galaxies at <em>z</em> ~ 1.5. In summary, the size of the GRAMOR's source does not lead to a problem regarding detectability.</p><h3 id=\"apj512980s5-1\" name=\"apj512980s5-1\">5.1.\u00a0Dependence on Lens Model Parameters</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>We first calculate the expected number distributions of GRAMORs for four types of clusters at <em>z</em> = 0.2 by fixing the other parameters. The result is shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj512980f4\">4</a>. From this figure, we find that a cluster with a smaller concentration parameter tends to produce more GRAMORs than one with a higher concentration parameter. This means that it is easier to observe GRAMORs in clusters with a mass distribution that is flat near the center. This is consistent with the fact that a cluster mass profile with a flat central core can easily give rise to an undistorted images as pointed out in earlier studies (Futamase et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib11\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib11\">1998</a>; Williams &amp; Lewis <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib32\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib32\">1998</a>).</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj512980f4\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj512980f4\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f4_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 4.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 4.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f4_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 4.</strong>\u00a0Expected distributions for the four types of clusters evaluated, including Types A, B, C and D. The type and color of the lines follow the same description as in Figure <a href=\"#apj512980f2\">2</a>.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj512980f4\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadFigure/figure/apj512980f4\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj512980f4\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj512980f4\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div><h3 id=\"apj512980s5-2\" name=\"apj512980s5-2\">5.2.\u00a0Dependence on Lens Redshift</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>We shall now consider the dependence of the expected number of GRAMORs on lens redshift. We choose <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub> = 0.2, 0.3, 0.544, and 0.7. <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub> = 0.544 is the redshift of MACS J1149.5+2223 in which a GRAMOR has been observed. Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj512980t2\">2</a> shows the expected number for each lens model and each lens redshift. From this table, we find a strong dependence on the lens redshift for any lens model. In particular, GRAMORs are likely to be observed for the lens models B and D at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn50.gif\" alt=\"${{z}_{l}}=0.544$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{z}_{l}}=0.544</script></span></span> and rarely observed for lens model A at any redshift. Thus, we further consider lens models B and D to investigate other dependencies of the expected number. We show the lens redshift dependence in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj512980f5\">5</a>. which clearly shows a strong dependence on source redshift. In particular, the distribution in the case of <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub> = 0.544 has a sharp peak at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn51.gif\" alt=\"${{z}_{s}}\\sim 1.49$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{z}_{s}}\\sim 1.49</script></span></span> for lens model D which is close to the observed redshift <em>z</em> = 1.4907.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj512980f5\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj512980f5\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f5_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 5.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 5.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f5_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 5.</strong>\u00a0Dependence on the lens redshift shown for the type D lens model. The solid line, dashed line, dotted line and dotted\u2013dashed line show the results with <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn52.gif\" alt=\"${{z}_{l}}=0.2,{{z}_{l}}=0.3,{{z}_{l}}=0.544$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{z}_{l}}=0.2,{{z}_{l}}=0.3,{{z}_{l}}=0.544</script></span></span> and <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub> = 0.7, respectively.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj512980f5\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadFigure/figure/apj512980f5\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj512980f5\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj512980f5\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apj512980t2\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 2.</b>\u00a0\nThe Expected Number of GRAMORs for Each Model\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj512980t2\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/suppdata/apj512980t2_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 2\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col></colgroup><thead>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub></th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.2</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.3</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.544</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.7</th>\n</tr>\n</thead><tbody>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">A</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.295387</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.601859</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.323144</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.161944</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">B</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.800333</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.798691</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.927403</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.479386</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">C</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.931151</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">1.174562</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">1.111886</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.564208</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">D</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">1.851518</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">1.998245</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">2.170035</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">1.114325</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/suppdata/apj512980t2_ascii.txt?doi=10.1088/0004-637X/805/2/184\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/suppdata/apj512980t2_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>Some of the distributions have two peaks which comes from the fact that there are two conditions that result in a GRAMOR. This result also shows that we can observe a sufficient number of GRAMORs to be used for lens statistics if a systematic survey for clusters with a relatively low concentration parameter is performed. The observational strategy will be mentioned later.</p></div><h3 id=\"apj512980s5-3\" name=\"apj512980s5-3\">5.3.\u00a0Dependence on the Definition of GRAMORs</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Next we consider how the definition of GRAMORs changes the results. So far, GRAMORs are defined as an image that has <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn53.gif\" alt=\"$1/3\\leqslant R\\leqslant 3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1/3\\leqslant R\\leqslant 3</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn54.gif\" alt=\"$10\\leqslant A$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">10\\leqslant A</script></span></span> as stated above. In this section, we compare the expected number distribution for images that have different conditions for magnification, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn55.gif\" alt=\"$10\\leqslant A$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">10\\leqslant A</script></span></span>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn56.gif\" alt=\"$20\\leqslant A$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">20\\leqslant A</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn57.gif\" alt=\"$30\\leqslant A$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">30\\leqslant A</script></span></span>. The result is shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj512980f6\">6</a>. Distributions with a larger magnification have peaks at a lower redshift. This comes from the fact that images at the higher redshift are too strongly distorted, so they do not satisfy the condition for distortion. The total numbers of observable GRAMORs are <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn58.gif\" alt=\"${{N}_{A\\geqslant 10}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{N}_{A\\geqslant 10}}</script></span></span> = 2.170335, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn59.gif\" alt=\"${{N}_{A\\geqslant 20}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{N}_{A\\geqslant 20}}</script></span></span> = 0.099358, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn60.gif\" alt=\"${{N}_{A\\geqslant 30}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{N}_{A\\geqslant 30}}</script></span></span> = 0.012873, respectively. Thus, highly magnified GRAMORs are very rare. However, if they are observed, they will constrain cosmological parameters much more severely as suggested by the argument below.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj512980f6\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj512980f6\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f6_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 6.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 6.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f6_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 6.</strong>\u00a0Dependence on the definition of GRAMORs is shown. The expected number is getting smaller with a more strict definition based on the value of the magnification parameter, <em>A</em>. The solid line, dashed line and dotted line represent the conditions of <em>A</em>, <em>A</em> <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn61.gif\" alt=\"$\\leqslant $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\leqslant</script></span></span> 10, <em>A</em> <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn62.gif\" alt=\"$\\leqslant $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\leqslant</script></span></span> 20 and <em>A</em> <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn63.gif\" alt=\"$\\leqslant $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\leqslant</script></span></span> 30, respectively.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj512980f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadFigure/figure/apj512980f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj512980f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj512980f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div><h3 id=\"apj512980s5-4\" name=\"apj512980s5-4\">5.4.\u00a0Dependence on the Cosmological Constant</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>As expected from the quasar statistics, GRAMOR statistics may have a strong dependence on the cosmological parameters. Here we concentrate on the dependence of lens statistics specifically on the cosmological constant. We also assume a totally flat geometry.</p><p>We calculate the PDF with three cosmological parameter sets, an Einstein\u2013de Sitter (EdS) universe, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn64.gif\" alt=\"$({{{\\Omega }}_{m}},{{{\\Omega }}_{{\\Lambda }}},h)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">({{{\\Omega }}_{m}},{{{\\Omega }}_{{\\Lambda }}},h)</script></span></span> = (1, 0, 0.73) the universe based on <em>WMAP</em>5 data, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn65.gif\" alt=\"$({{{\\Omega }}_{m}},{{{\\Omega }}_{{\\Lambda }}},h)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">({{{\\Omega }}_{m}},{{{\\Omega }}_{{\\Lambda }}},h)</script></span></span> = (0.24, 0.73, 0.73) and the universe based on Planck13 data, (Planck Collaboration et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj512980bib25\" id=\"fnref-apj512980bib25\">2014</a>), <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn66.gif\" alt=\"$({{{\\Omega }}_{m}},{{{\\Omega }}_{{\\Lambda }}},h)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">({{{\\Omega }}_{m}},{{{\\Omega }}_{{\\Lambda }}},h)</script></span></span> = (0.3175, 0.6825, 0.6711). The results are shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj512980f7\">7</a>, where we consider types B and D at <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub> = 0.544 as typical examples.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj512980f7\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj512980f7\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f7_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 7.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 7.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f7_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 7.</strong>\u00a0Dependence on the cosmological parameter for GRAMORs is shown. We employ three sets of cosmological parameters, based on the Einstein\u2013de Sitter universe, <em>WMAP</em> data and Planck data for lens types D and B. The plots show the normalized expected number distributions plotted against the total number, resulting in a probability distribution function (PDF) of source redshift for GRAMORs. The solid lines, dashed lines and dotted lines represent the EdS, <em>WMAP</em>5 and Planck data respectively. The red lines represent lens model D and the blue lines represent lens model B. The behaviors of the PDFs are similar regardless the lens type.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj512980f7\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadFigure/figure/apj512980f7\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj512980f7\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj512980f7\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>From this figure, one can immediately see differences between the three cosmologies. First, the peak shapes are different. For the EdS universe, the peak is higher and narrower than the others. Second, the peak redshifts are different. This figure indicates that if we find a GRAMOR with redshift <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn67.gif\" alt=\"${{z}_{s}}\\sim 1.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{z}_{s}}\\sim 1.5</script></span></span> in a cluster at <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub> = 0.544, the EdS universe will be rejected with a high probability. Furthermore, the shapes of the peaks have a non-negligible difference between <em>WMAP</em> cosmology and Planck cosmology. Thus if we observe a large number of GRAMORs and their redshift distribution, more stringent constraints for the cosmological constant will be obtained by combining them with other observations such as CMB, and BAO. We will come back to this point later using a more realistic lens model for the cluster MACS J1149.5+2223 in the next subsection.</p><p>This is a unique property of GRAMORs. In fact if we perform the same calculation for an arc with the definition of an arc being <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn68.gif\" alt=\"$R\\geqslant 10$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">R\\geqslant 10</script></span></span>, then the result is as shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj512980f8\">8</a>. The conditions of the calculation are same as that for GRAMORs, but there are no big differences in the peak positions between the two types of cosmological models for the arc. The reason for this difference may be found in the dependence of the distortion parameter <em>R</em> and the magnification parameter <em>A</em> on the cosmological parameters. The parameter used for defining the arc is only <em>R</em> and the behavior of <em>R</em> in the EdS and \u039bCDM universes is shown in Figures <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj512980f9\">9</a> and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj512980f10\">10</a> respectively. The color of the line corresponds to the redshift of the source. In both cases, the area where images are distorted becomes larger and moves to outside the lens as the source redshift increases. The increasing rate of the area with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn69.gif\" alt=\"$10\\leqslant R$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">10\\leqslant R</script></span></span> is not so different in the two types of cosmology. The size of the area is different but it does not have a big effect because the final result is normalized. Likewise, the dependence of the expected number of arcs on cosmological parameters is not so strong.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj512980f8\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj512980f8\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f8_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 8.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 8.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f8_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 8.</strong>\u00a0Dependence on the cosmological parameter for arcs for lens model D is shown. The color and type of the line and the cosmological parameters used are the same\u2014bf with those used in Figure <a href=\"#apj512980f7\">7</a>.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj512980f8\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadFigure/figure/apj512980f8\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj512980f8\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj512980f8\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj512980f9\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj512980f9\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f9_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 9.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 9.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f9_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 9.</strong>\u00a0Behavior of <em>R</em> in the Einstein\u2013de Sitter universe with changing source redshifts. The abscissa is the lens radius in units of scale radius, <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn70.gif\" alt=\"$x\\equiv r/{{r}_{s}}.$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">x\\equiv r/{{r}_{s}}.</script></span></span> The solid line, dashed line and dotted line represent <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> = 0.8, <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> = 1.2 and <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> = 1.5, respectively. The horizontal lines show the upper and lower limits of <em>R</em> for the definition of GRAMORs.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj512980f9\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadFigure/figure/apj512980f9\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj512980f9\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj512980f9\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj512980f10\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj512980f10\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f10_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 10.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 10.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f10_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 10.</strong>\u00a0Graph using the same conditions as in Figure <a href=\"#apj512980f9\">9</a>, but we use the \u039bCDM universe and add the results with <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> = 2.0.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj512980f10\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadFigure/figure/apj512980f10\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj512980f10\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj512980f10\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>However, the behavior of <em>A</em> with EdS cosmological parameters changes rapidly. Figures <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj512980f11\">11</a> and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj512980f12\">12</a> illustrate this property. Even if the source redshift is low, the area where the condition <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn71.gif\" alt=\"$10\\leqslant A$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">10\\leqslant A</script></span></span> is satisfied decreases as the source redshift becomes higher. It is easy to understand this by comparing with the graph of <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> = 1.5. The range of values that satisfy <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn72.gif\" alt=\"$10\\leqslant A$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">10\\leqslant A</script></span></span> in the EdS universe is about <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn73.gif\" alt=\"$0.17\\leqslant x\\leqslant 0.22$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0.17\\leqslant x\\leqslant 0.22</script></span></span>, while that for \u039bCDM is about <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn74.gif\" alt=\"$0.08\\leqslant x\\leqslant 0.4$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0.08\\leqslant x\\leqslant 0.4</script></span></span>. Thus, the rate of change for <em>A</em> in the EdS universe is greater than that for \u039bCDM. This leads to the result that the PDF calculated based on the EdS universe is limited to the low redshift range.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj512980f11\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj512980f11\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f11_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 11.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 11.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f11_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 11.</strong>\u00a0Behavior of <em>A</em> with the Einstein\u2013de Sitter universe model. The lines are the same as in Figure <a href=\"#apj512980f9\">9</a>. The horizontal line is the lower limit of <em>A</em> for the definition of GRAMORs.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj512980f11\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadFigure/figure/apj512980f11\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj512980f11\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj512980f11\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj512980f12\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj512980f12\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f12_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 12.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 12.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f12_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 12.</strong>\u00a0Graph using the same conditions as in Figure <a href=\"#apj512980f11\">11</a>, but we use the \u039bCDM universe and add the results with <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> = 2.0.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj512980f12\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadFigure/figure/apj512980f12\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj512980f12\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj512980f12\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>In short, the reason why there is a big difference in the dependence on cosmological parameters of the PDFs between arcs and GRAMORs is that a GRAMOR has a dependence on <em>A</em>, but an arc does not.</p></div><h3 id=\"apj512980s5-5\" name=\"apj512980s5-5\">5.5.\u00a0MACSJ1149.5+2223</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>MACSJ1149.5+2223 is currently the only known cluster in which a GRAMOR has been observed. Here, we apply our calculation to this cluster. We use Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj512980eqn22\">22</a>) as the profile of MACSJ1149.5+2223 derived in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj512980s3\">3</a> and set <em>z</em><sub><em>l</em></sub> = 0.544 and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn75.gif\" alt=\"$22\\leqslant A\\leqslant 24$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">22\\leqslant A\\leqslant 24</script></span></span>. Regarding the observed GRAMOR, the magnification is estimated to be <em>A</em> = 23 although there is no data for <em>R</em> although it looks nearly face-on. We will set only the magnification limit here.</p><p>We use the two cosmological models \u039bCDM and EdS, as in the case of calculations with the NFW profile. Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj512980f13\">13</a> shows the PDFs calculated with each cosmology. As shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj512980f13\">13</a>, there are large differences between the two cases. We focus on the region around <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn76.gif\" alt=\"${{z}_{s}}\\sim 1.49$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{z}_{s}}\\sim 1.49</script></span></span>, which is the source redshift of the observed GRAMOR. In this region, the possibility in the case of the \u039bCDM universe is about twice as high as that in the case of the EdS universe. The peak position of the PDF is at around <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn77.gif\" alt=\"${{z}_{s}}\\sim 1.6$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{z}_{s}}\\sim 1.6</script></span></span> in the \u039bCDM case, and about <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn78.gif\" alt=\"${{z}_{s}}\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{z}_{s}}\\sim 2</script></span></span> in the EdS case. Thus, the \u039bCDM universe is more preferable compared to the EdS universe. According to the HFF project, there have been 38 lensed images in 13 families in MACS J1149.5+2223 observed in addition to the GRAMOR by <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"webref\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://www.stsci.edu/hst/campaigns/frontier-fields/\">http://www.stsci.edu/hst/campaigns/frontier-fields/</a>). If we use these images in addition to the observed GRAMOR, we would get more severe constraints, which is the subject of a future study. A more detailed study of this GRAMOR and its dependence on the cosmological parameters using a realistic mass reconstruction for MACS J1149.5+2223 will be presented elsewhere (A. T. Lefor et al. 2015, in preparation)</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj512980f13\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj512980f13\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f13_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 13.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 13.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980f13_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 13.</strong>\u00a0PDFs with the profile of MACSJ1149.5+2223. The solid line and dotted line represent the the \u039bCDM and Einstein\u2013de Sitter universes respectively.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj512980f13\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadFigure/figure/apj512980f13\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj512980f13\" href=\"/0004-637X/805/2/184/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj512980f13\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj512980s6\" name=\"apj512980s6\">6.\u00a0DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSIONS</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>In this paper, we studied the lens statistics for GRAMORs, which are gravitationally highly magnified yet morphologically regular images. We calculated the expected number distribution of GRAMORs as a function of source redshift changing several conditions.</p><p>First, we used four types of lens model with an NFW profile suggested by weak lensing studies of the LoCuSS clusters. The dependence on the mass profile, especially the concentration parameter, becomes clear. The cluster with a flat core produces more GRAMORs which is consistent with previous investigations.</p><p>Second, we consider various values of lens redshift and found that the distribution has a sharp peak in most cases. In particular the peak becomes more sharp for clusters with a higher redshift. We also found that the number of GRAMORs is expected to be ~2.1 per cluster in the most likely case. This means that a sufficient number of GRAMORs can be expected to be observed based on the statistics if we perform a systematic survey.</p><p>We then consider GRAMOR statistics for three types of cosmological models, the EdS universe, universes with parameters obtained using <em>WMAP</em> data, and those using Planck data. We find that the expected number of GRAMORs and their distribution depends strongly on the cosmological parameters. This suggests a possible method to constrain the value of the cosmological constant. Namely by observing a large number of GRAMORs and their redshift distributions, a stringent constraint for the cosmological constant will be obtained by combining this data with other observations such as CMB and BAO. Although we consider the case of the cosmological constant for simplicity, we expect that this method using GRAMORs may be useful to study the properties of dark energy as well.</p><p>We also calculated the PDF in a model of MACSJ1149.5+2223 with two cosmological models. The result shows a large difference between the two models. The peak position in the PDF is at about <em>z</em> = 1.6 for the \u039bCDM universe which is close to the observed value of <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> = 1.4906, while the PDF has a peak at about <em>z</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> = 2 in the EdS model. It is rather surprising that only one system MACSJ1149.5+2223 and one image can result in a strong constraint on the existence of the cosmological constant.</p><p>Finally we describe an observational strategy to identify GRAMORs. Since GRAMORs are likely to be observed in clusters of galaxies with relatively low concentration and the source redshift dependence is sharply peaked for high-<em>z</em> clusters, we first make a sample of such clusters with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/805/2/184/Full/apj512980ieqn79.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 0.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 0.5</script></span></span>, for example. Then the peak of the source redshift distribution is at approximately <em>z</em> = 1.5 depending on the cosmology. High-resolution multi-color imaging and/or an infrared narrow band filter should be used to identify GRAMORs. By performing multi-color imaging, we can select the source galaxies which exist around the peak of the source redshift distribution. Planned space satellites such as <em>James Webb Space Telescope (JWST)</em>, WFIRST, EUCLID, WISH are most appropriate for such a survey.</p></div> <div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We thank K. Umetsu and Y. Okura for many helpful suggestions and useful discussions. We also thank N. Okabe for providing the cluster date and helpful suggestions. Finally we thank Alan Lefor for useful discussions and improving the English usage. This work is supported in part by Grant-in-Aid from Science and Research Council (No. 26400264 for T.F.).</p></div></div><!-- End article full text -->\n<!-- Start Footnotes -->\n\t<!-- End Footnotes Licensed MIT */\n\tfunction loadJS( src, cb ){\n\t  \"use strict\";\n\t  var ref = window.document.getElementsByTagName( \"script\" )[ 0 ];\n\t  var script = window.document.createElement( \"script\" );\n\t  script.src = src;\n\t  script.async = true;\n\t  ref.parentNode.insertBefore( script, ref );\n\t  if (cb && typeof(cb) === \"function\") {\n\t\tscript.onload = cb;\n\t  }\n\t  return script;\n\t}\n\n\tloadJS( \"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/js/scripts.min.js\" );\n\n  }\n</script>\n\n<script type=\"text/javascript\">window.NREUM||(NREUM={});NREUM.info={\"errorBeacon\":\"bam-cell.nr-data.net\",\"licenseKey\":\"b2bfaae1b6\",\"agent\":\"\",\"beacon\":\"bam-cell.nr-data.net\",\"applicationTime\":360,\"applicationID\":\"723879338\",\"transactionName\":\"NAAHMUBVCENSABFZXg1KLzZiGzF1cU4sfndMDxYVQRsFX14OCl4eDwQcCkdASFpAEw==\",\"queueTime\":0}</script></body>\n</html>", "ADS link": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2015ApJ...805..184M", "Tables status": "Complete", "Inspection status": "Incomplete", "Paper Overview": {"abstract": "GRAMORs are GRAvitationally highly magnified yet MORphologically regular images. An example of this phenomenon was discovered in the cluster MACS J1149.5+2223 in 2009. We investigate the lens statistics of GRAMORs in detail. Assuming a NFW profile for a sample of clusters, we calculate the expected number and redshift distribution of GRAMORs using parameters from COSMOS data for the number density of the background galaxy. A model with a cluster placed at z = 0.544 based on WMAP5 cosmology predicts the redshift of a GRAMOR at z\u2243 1.49 which is close to the observed z = 1.4906. These results show that the expected number of GRAMORs is about two per cluster in the most likely case, and thus a large number of GRAMORs would be observed in a systematic survey. The probability distribution function of source redshift for GRAMORs depends strongly on dark energy and may be useful for constraining the nature of dark energy.", "start_page": "184", "authors": ["Morioka, Masayo", "Futamase, Toshifumi"], "issn": "0004-637X", "Title": "Lens Statistics with Gravitationally Lensed yet Morphologically Regular Images", "type_of_reference": "JOUR", "keywords": ["cosmological parameters", "galaxies: clusters: general", "galaxies: clusters: individual: MACSJ1149.5+2223", "gravitational lensing: strong"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2015ApJ...805..184M", "journal_name": "The Astrophysical Journal", "volume": "805", "number": "2", "publication_year": "2015/06/1", "doi": "10.1088/0004-637X/805/2/184", "author_address": ["AA(Astronomical Institute, Tohoku University, Aramaki, Aoba, Sendai 980-8578, Japan), AB(Astronomical Institute, Tohoku University, Aramaki, Aoba, Sendai 980-8578, Japan)"]}, "Action": "Scanned and processed all tables", "Status": "Complete", "Publisher link via ADS gateway": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/link_gateway/2015ApJ...805..184M/PUB_HTML"}

<main role=\"main\">\n        <!-- Secondary header starts -->\n<div class=\"secondary-header cf\" id=\"wd-secondary-header\">\n    <!-- Branded journal header starts -->\n<div class=\"big-branded\">\n\n    <div class=\"publication-name\" id=\"wd-pub-name\">\n\t<div class=\"publication-title\" itemprop=\"name\" itemid=\"periodical\">\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Journal image link tile starts -->\n<!-- Logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"/journal/0004-637X\" itemprop=\"url\">\n    <img src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8febf88b-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/apj-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Astrophysical Journal\">\n</a>\n<!-- Logo tile ends -->\n<!-- Journal image link tile ends -->\n</div>\n\t\t</div>\n    <div class=\"partner-logos m-hide\" id=\"wd-partner-logos\">\n            <div class=\"partner-logo-alignment\">\n                <!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The American Astronomical Society (AAS), established in 1899 and based in Washington, DC, is the major organization of professional astronomers in North America. Its membership of about 7,000 individuals also includes physicists, mathematicians, geologists, engineers, and others whose research and educational interests lie within the broad spectrum of subjects comprising contemporary astronomy. The mission of the AAS is to enhance and share humanity's scientific understanding of the universe.</p> <p><a href=\"https://aas.org/\">https://aas.org/</a></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The Institute of Physics (IOP) is a leading scientific society promoting physics and bringing physicists together for the benefit of all. It has a worldwide membership of around 50 000 comprising physicists from all sectors, as well as those with an interest in physics. It works to advance physics research, application and education; and engages with policy makers and the public to develop awareness and understanding of physics. Its publishing company, IOP Publishing, is a world leader in professional scientific communications.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.iop.org\">https://www.iop.org</a></p></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<p></p>\n                </div>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n<!-- Branded journal header ends -->\n</div> <!-- end secondary-header -->\n<!-- Secondary header ends --><div class=\"da1-da2\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ScholarlyArticle\" id=\"page-content\">\n            <div class=\"da1 ta1 article-head\">\n                <!-- Start Eyebrow block, containing Surtitle and Labels -->\n<div class=\"eyebrow\">\n\t<!-- Start Collection Labels -->\n    <!-- End Collection Labels --> </div>\n<!-- End Eyebrow block -->\n\n<h1 itemprop=\"headline\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-title\">LENS STATISTICS WITH GRAVITATIONALLY LENSED YET MORPHOLOGICALLY REGULAR IMAGES</h1>\n\n<p class=\"mb-0\">\n\t<span data-authors=\"\">\n\t\t<span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">Masayo Morioka</span><a 88.7 56.8z\"></path></svg></a></span> and <span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">Toshifumi Futamase</span></span></span>\n</p>\n\n<p class=\"small\" itemprop=\"isPartOf\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/PublicationIssue\">\n\t<!--Article Breadcrumb Tile Start-->\n<span class=\"wd-jnl-art-pub-date\">Published 2015 June 2</span> &bull; <!-- Start Copyright-->\n    <span itemprop=\"copyrightHolder\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-copyright\">\n       \t  \u00a9 2015. src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/icon-mendeley.svg\" alt=\"Share on Mendeley\">\n\t</a>\n\t</li>\n</ul>\n<div class=\"clear-fl\"></div>\n</div>\n\n</div>\n</div>\n            <div class=\"da1 ta1\">\n                <!-- Start Linked Articles note -->\n\t<!-- End Linked Articles note -->\n<!-- Article information starts. This includes author emails, affiliations, article published date, doi etc. -->\n\t<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon bdt-1 wd-jnl-art-article-info-wrapper\">\n      \t<div class=\"replica-h3 mt-0\">\n        \t<a id=\"wd-article-info-accordion\" href=\"#\" class=\"reveal-trigger\" data-reveal-label-alt=\"Hide article information\">Article information</a>\n      \t</div>\n      \t<div class=\"reveal-content\">\n        \t<div class=\"article-meta\">\n          \t\t<!-- Start Authors --><div class=\"wd-jnl-art-email-addresses\"><div class=\"replica-h4\">Author e-mails</div><p class=\"mb-0\"><a href=\"mailto:mmori@astro.tohoku.ac.jp\" title=\"Send mail to mmori@astro.tohoku.ac.jp\">mmori@astro.tohoku.ac.jp</a></p><p class=\"mb-0\"><a href=\"mailto:tof@astr.tohoku.ac.jp\" title=\"Send mail to tof@astr.tohoku.ac.jp\">tof@astr.tohoku.ac.jp</a></p></div><!-- End Authors --><!-- Start Affiliations --><div class=\"wd-jnl-art-author-affiliations\"><div class=\"replica-h4\">Author affiliations</div><p class=\"mb-05\">Astronomical Institute, Tohoku University, Aramaki, Aoba, Sendai 980-8578, Japan</p></div><!-- End Affiliations --><!-- Start ORCIDs --><div class=\"wd-jnl-art-author-orcid-list\"><div class=\"replica-h4\">ORCID iDs</div><p class=\"mb-05\"><span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">Masayo Morioka</span><a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0001-7438-6274\" title=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0001-7438-6274\"><svg xmlns=\"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg\" viewBox=\"0 0 256 256\" width=\"20\" class=\"orcid-logo\"><path class=\"st0\" d=\"M256 128c0 70.7-57.3 128-128 128C57.3 256 0 198.7 0 128 0 57.3 57.3 0 128 0 198.7 0 256 57.3 256 128z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M86.3 56.8z\"></path></svg> https://orcid.org/0000-0001-7438-6274</a></span></p></div><!-- End ORCIDs --><!-- Start Dates -->\n<div class=\"col-no-break wd-jnl-art-dates\">\n        <div class=\"replica-h4\">Dates</div>\n        <p>\n            \n                Received <span itemprop=\"dateReceived\">2014 August 18</span><br />\n            \n                Accepted <span itemprop=\"dateAccepted\">2015 April 9</span><br />\n            \n                    Published <span itemprop=\"datePublished\">2015 June 2</span><br />\n                </p>\n    </div>\n<!-- End Dates -->\n\n<!-- Start Crossmark -->\n\t\t\t\t<!-- End Crossmark -->\n\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Start Peer Review Metrics -->\n<!-- End Peer Review Metrics -->\n\n<!--  Start Citation -->\n                    <!--  End Citation -->\n\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Start DOI -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"col-no-break wd-jnl-art-doi\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"replica-h4\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<abbr title=\"digital object identifier\">DOI</abbr>\n\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t<p><a itemprop=\"sameAs\" href=\"https://doi.org/10.1088/0004-637X/805/2/184\">https://doi.org/10.1088/0004-637X/805/2/184</a></p>\n\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t<!-- End DOI -->\n\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Start Accepted manuscript Link -->\n<!-- End Accepted manuscript Link -->\n<!-- Start Annotations -->\n <!-- End Annotations --><div class=\"col-no-break wd-jnl-aas-keywords\">\n\t\t<div class=\"replica-h4\">Keywords</div>\n\t\t<p><a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=11%2F46&amp;code_desc=cosmological+parameters\">cosmological parameters</a>; <a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=11%2F6&amp;code_desc=galaxies%3A+clusters%3A+general\">galaxies: clusters: general</a>; <a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=11%2F7&amp;code_desc=galaxies%3A+clusters%3A+individual\">galaxies: clusters: individual</a><a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_sub&amp;code=11%2F7&amp;code_desc=galaxies%3A+clusters%3A+individual&amp;subkwd=MACSJ1149_5_plus_2223&amp;subkwd_desc=MACSJ1149.5%2B2223\">\n\t\t\t\t(MACSJ1149.5+2223)\n\t\t\t</a>; <a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=2%2F46&amp;code_desc=gravitational+lensing%3A+strong\">gravitational lensing: strong</a></p>\n\t</div>\n<!-- Start Reprint Link -->\n\t<!-- End Reprint Link --><!-- Start Journal RSS feed -->\n                    <div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper jnl-notifications-wrapper--rss\">\n                        <a class=\"wd-jnl-rss\" href=\"/journal/rss/0004-637X\"><span\n                                class=\"icon-feed icon-feed--jhp\"></span>Journal RSS</a>\n                    </div>\n\t\t\t\t\t<!-- End Journal RSS feed -->\n\t\t\t\t\t<!-- Start Email Alert -->\n    <!-- Start Email Alert -->\n        <div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper\">\n            <a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert id=\"corridors-create-manage\" title=\"Create or edit your corridor alerts\">\n                <span class=\"icon-alarm icon-alarm--jhp\"></span>Create or edit your corridor alerts\n            </a>\n\n<!-- Start TOC Subjects Popup -->\n<span class=\"overlay-set\" id=\"corridor-alerts-overlay\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel two-columns\">\n
